intro: Isocarpha amellus, commonly known as the narrowleaf sedge, is a herbaceous perennial plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, three-lobed flowers arranged in spikelets. The plant typically grows in wet or moist environments, such as marshes and pond edges, and is native to parts of Europe and Asia. Isocarpha amellus has a fibrous root system and can form dense stands in suitable habitats. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
